questions.text: A child presents with brown colored urine and oliguria for last 3 days. He has mild facial and pedal edema. His blood pressure is 126/90. He has +3 proteinuria with 100 red cell and a few granular casts. His creatinine is 0.9, urea is 56. What is his diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

PSGN The above clinical presentation suggests PSGN in the child. PSGN is a kidney disease (glomerulonephritis) that can develop after infections caused by bacteria called group A Streptococcus (group A strep). These infections include throat and skin infections like strep throat, scarlet fever, and impetigo. Clinical features: Age of presentation – 5 – 12 years Onset with puffiness around the eyes + pedal edema. Presents with hematuria with smoky, cola coloured urine (about 1-4 weeks after throat infection) & hypertension C3 levels are reduced Diagnosis: Light microscopy – Proliferation of endothelial & mesangial cells (on EM lumpy bumpy deposits on GBM) RBC casts in urine Urine shows 1 -2 + proteinuria High ASO tilt (NORMALIZES IN 6 WEEKS) Treatment - Symptomatic

Highyeild:

PSGN ( Post-Streptococcal Glomerulonephritis ) is an immune-mediated glomerulonephritis that typically occurs after an infection, usually a streptococcal infection, such as strep throat or a skin infection. The characteristic features of PSGN include brown-colored urine (due to the presence of red blood cells), oliguria (decreased urine output), mild facial and pedal edema, and hypertension.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- OPTION B: Nephrolithiasis refers to the presence of kidney stones, and the clinical presentation and laboratory findings in the question are not consistent with this condition. OPTION C: FSGN (Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis) is a different type of glomerulonephritis that typically presents with nephrotic syndrome (heavy proteinuria, edema, hypoalbuminemia). The clinical findings mentioned in the question, such as oliguria, brown-colored urine, and hypertension, are not typically associated with FSGN. OPTION D: Infection-associated glomerulonephritis is a broad term that encompasses various types of glomerulonephritis that can occur secondary to infections. PSGN is a specific subtype of infection-associated glomerulonephritis, and the child's clinical presentation and laboratory findings are consistent with PSGN rather than other types.

Extraedge:

The diagnosis of PSGN is typically made based on clinical presentation, history of preceding streptococcal infection, urinalysis findings, and supporting laboratory tests. This may include serological tests to detect evidence of streptococcal infection, such as elevated anti-streptolysin O (ASO) titers.

#MANTRA Clinical Presentation - Brown-colored urine - Oliguria - Mild facial and pedal edema - Blood pressure: 126/90 Laboratory Findings - Proteinuria: +3 - Red blood cells: 100 - Granular casts - Creatinine: 0.9 - Urea: 56 Diagnosis - PSGN (Post-Streptococcal Glomerulonephritis) - PSGN is caused by an immune response to a preceding streptococcal infection - Infection is usually due to group A beta-hemolytic streptococcus - Serological tests can help detect evidence of streptococcal infection - Treatment focuses on managing symptoms, controlling blood pressure, and supporting kidney function

questions.text: An 18 months old baby brought to hospital due to abnormal twitching of his lower limb. On examination he had low grade fever with fontanelle bulging. What can be most common cause:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Meningitis Child with fever, twitching of lower limb and bulging fontanelle suggests meningitis with raised intracranial pressure.

Highyeild:

Meningitis refers to the inflammation of the meninges, the protective membranes surrounding the brain and spinal cord. It is commonly caused by a bacterial or viral infection. The symptoms of meningitis can include fever, neck stiffness, altered mental status, seizures, and fontanelle bulging in infants.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- OPTION B. Febrile seizure: Febrile seizures are seizures that occur in response to a high fever, commonly seen in young children. They are usually brief, generalized seizures and have a good prognosis without long-term neurological damage. OPTION C. Pseudotumor cerebri ( Idiopathic Intracranial Hypertension) : Pseudotumor cerebri is a condition characterized by increased intracranial pressure without the presence of a tumor. It commonly presents with symptoms such as headaches, visual disturbances, and sometimes papilledema (swelling of the optic disc). OPTION D. Intracranial hemorrhage: Intracranial hemorrhage refers to bleeding within the brain or the surrounding spaces. It can result from various causes, including trauma, vascular abnormalities, or coagulation disorders. Intracranial hemorrhage can lead to neurological symptoms depending on the location and severity of the bleed.

Extraedge:

In suspected cases of meningitis, diagnostic tests such as a lumbar puncture (spinal tap) are performed to analyze cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). CSF analysis includes examination for cell count, glucose, protein, and cultures to identify the infectious agent.

questions.text: A 3 week neonate presents with ambiguous genitalia with Na+ -127, K+-6mEq, along with IV fluids, what specific management is done?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hydrocortisone The given lab findings in a child with ambiguous genitalia points to the diagnosis of Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH). The term congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) encompasses a group of autosomal recessive disorders, each of which involves a deficiency of an enzyme involved in the synthesis of cortisol, aldosterone, or both. The diagnosis of CAH depends on the demonstration of inadequate production of cortisol, aldosterone, or both in the presence of accumulation of excess concentrations of precursor hormones. Management guidelines of CAH include: Glucocorticoid replacement is the cornerstone of replacement therapy in CAH. The drug of choice in children is hydrocortisone. This drug should be administered in tablet form which can be crushed and mixed with milk or liquid as fresh preparation before administration. Other potent forms of glucocorticoids like prednisolone and dexamethasone are not recommended for use in early childhood years but can be used in postpubertal and adult patients Mineralocorticoid replacement is encouraged in CAH with salt-wasting; in infants, mineralocorticoid replacement (usually with fludrocortisones) and sodium supplementation are encouraged.

Highyeild:

Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH): CAH is a group of autosomal recessive disorders affecting steroid synthesis. The most common form of CAH is 21-hydroxylase deficiency. CAH leads to deficiencies in adrenal hormones and excess steroid precursors. CAH has a spectrum of forms, including salt-wasting, simple virilizing, and non-classic forms. Diagnosis involves measuring elevated levels of 17-hydroxyprogesterone. Management includes lifelong steroid replacement therapy. Hydrocortisone and fludrocortisone are used for salt-wasting and virilizing forms. Synthetic glucocorticoids may be used after growth and pubertal development. Other enzyme deficiencies account for a minority of CAH cases. Specific management is required for these less common forms.

questions.text: For the following question, there is an Assertion - (A) and Reasoning - (R) statement. Mark the correct/True option as per the following direction: Select one of the following: Assertion – (A): Antibiotics are the main line of treatment in neonatal diarrhea. Reason – (R): Majority of diarrhea in neonate is due to virus.

options.label: A
options.text: Both Assertion and Reasons are independently true / correct statements and the Reason is the true / correct explanation for the Assertion

options.label: B
options.text: Both Assertion and Reasons are independently true / correct statements, but the Reason is not the true / correct explanation for the Assertion

options.label: C
options.text: Assertion is independently a true / correct statement, but the Reasons is independently a false / incorrect statement

options.label: D
options.text: Assertion is independently a false / incorrect statement, but the Reasons is independently a true / correct statement

questions.correct_answer: D. Assertion is independently a false / incorrect statement, but the Reasons is independently a true / correct statement
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Assertion is independently a false / incorrect statement, but the Reasons is independently a true / correct statement Assertion is false because ORS is the mainstay of treatment in diarrhea. However it is noteworthy that diarrhea in neonates can often be a symptom presentation of sepsis; and therefore a high degree of suspicion should be kept in mind and antibiotics started if sepsis confirmed. A short empirical course of antibiotics till investigations rule out septicemia is also followed as a treatment approach by many pediatricians, although it is not routinely recommended. The most common cause of diarrhea in children is viruses, among which Rotavirus is the most common cause

Highyeild:

Neonatal diarrhea can have various causes, including viral, bacterial, and parasitic infections. Viruses are commonly associated with neonatal diarrhea, particularly rotavirus and norovirus. Neonatal diarrhea can be transmitted through contaminated food or water, poor hygiene practices, or direct contact with infected individuals.

Extraedge:

The management of neonatal diarrhea focuses on preventing dehydration and providing supportive care. Oral rehydration therapy (ORT) is the mainstay of treatment to maintain fluid and electrolyte balance. In some cases, specific treatments such as antiviral medications or antibiotics may be prescribed if a particular pathogen is identified.

questions.text: A 6 years old child with developmental delay, can ride a tricycle, can climb upstairs with alternate foot, can say name, knows own sex, but cannot narrate a story. What is the developmental age:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

3 years Milestones mastered by 3 years of age : Gross Motor Skills Stand without support (mastered by 12 months) Run and walk without tripping over own feet Walk backwards and climb upstairs alternate foot per step (usually can go both upstairs and downstairs alternate foot per step by 4 years) Start pedaling a tricycle Fine Motor Skills Draw a line and a circle with a crayon, pencil, or marker Play with toys that have small moving parts and/or buttons Turn the pages of a book singly (mastered by 2 years) Build towers of six or more blocks (6 blocks by 2 years and 10 blocks by 3 years) Work door handles and open twist-on bottle tops The child knows own gender by 3 years; but narrates a story by 4 years.

Highyeild:

Physical: Improved coordination, can climb stairs and ride a tricycle. Cognitive: Sorts objects, completes simple puzzles, engages in pretend play. Language: Speaks in 3- to 4-word sentences, uses pronouns correctly, asks simple questions. Social/Emotional: Shows increased independence, plays and shares with other children, begins to understand and express feelings.

questions.text: Effective sign of neonatal resuscitation is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Heart rate increased Increase in heart rate is considered as the most effective sign of neonatal resuscitation. Upon child’s birth the basic steps to be followed after assessment and confirmation for term gestation; good breathing; and normal tone; in most babies is routine care – Positioning/warmth Suction (routine suctioning is now not recommended in most guidelines) Drying Stimulating, usually by rubbing back or flicking the soles In other Cases steps of resuscitation are provided as mentioned below (and shown in the diagram) PPV (for apnea or gasping; HR < 100/m); and SPO2 monitoring with/without O2 in case of labored breathing Chest compression with intubation (especially when HR < 60/m) IV/intratracheal epinephrine

Highyeild:

Signs of successful neonatal resuscitation include : spontaneous breathing, increased heart rate, improved color, active movement, a good cry, and improved oxygen saturation. These signs indicate that the baby is responding well to resuscitative efforts and is recovering.

questions.text: Gene involved in Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

GABRA-1 The gene involved in Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy is GABRA-1. Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (JME) is an idiopathic generalized epileptic syndrome characterized by myoclonic jerks, generalized tonic-clonic seizures (GTCSs), and sometimes absence seizures. Typical EEG pattern is 4-6 Hz polyspike with slow wave discharges. Overall prognosis is good. Valproate is the DOC. When the condition is caused by mutations in the GABRA1 gene, it is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy is associated with GABRA – 1 EFHC – 1 CACNB – 4

Highyeild:

Juvenile Myoclonic epilepsy. (Janz syndrome) is characterised by: Myoclonic epilepsy. occurs during the early morning hours Electroencephalogram (EEG) shows slow wave discharges with 4-6 spike waves Usually in adolescents Due to sleep deprivation Valproate is used Gamma-aminobutyric acid type A receptor alpha1 subunit (GABRA1), Calcium-sensing receptor (CASR), and Calcium channel beta 4(CACNB4) are genes involved.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- OPTION A: CHYNN1 : CHYNN1 (Chymotrypsin-like elastase family member 1) is a gene involved in neurodevelopment and has been associated with intellectual disability and autism spectrum disorders. OPTION C: FMR1 : FMR1 (Fragile X Mental Retardation 1) is a gene associated with Fragile X syndrome, which is a genetic condition causing intellectual disability and developmental delays. While individuals with Fragile X syndrome may experience seizures, it is a distinct condition from Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy, and FMR1 is not directly associated with JME.

Extraedge:

EFHC1 (EF-hand domain-containing 1): Mutations in this gene have been found in some individuals with JME. CACNB4 (Calcium Channel, Voltage-dependent, Beta 4 Subunit): Variations in this gene have also been linked to JME. GABRA1 (Gamma-aminobutyric acid receptor subunit alpha-1): While not specifically associated with JME, mutations in this gene have been identified in some forms of epilepsy, but their role in JME is not well-established.
